modules.title: AT-1: Security Awareness & Training Policy and Procedures
modules.description: Learn about ClearTriage's Security and Privacy Awareness Training Policy, procedures, and our commitment to FedRAMP compliance
objectives: Understand ClearTriage's Security and Privacy Awareness Training Policy
Learn about roles and responsibilities in our security training program
Identify how policies are reviewed, updated, and disseminated

content.title: Welcome to ClearTriage Security Training
content.content: Welcome to ClearTriage's Security and Privacy Awareness Training! This training is designed to help our 6-person team understand and meet our FedRAMP Low Impact SaaS (LI-SaaS) requirements. We're working toward FedRAMP authorization for our app running in AWS and Google Drive usage for the VA. Security is everyone's job â€“ even in a small company!

content.title: Our Security Training Policy
content.content: We have a formal Security and Privacy Awareness and Training Policy that outlines how we conduct security training and maintain awareness. The policy is documented, accessible in Google Drive, and disseminated to all six team members. Pete Allen (CTO) owns the training program and is your primary contact for security questions at pete@cleartriage.com, with Dave as backup.

content.title: Roles and Responsibilities
content.content: Pete Allen (CTO) is responsible for developing and updating training materials and ensuring everyone completes training on time. Our small size means no one slips through the cracks. Dave (President) serves as backup contact and brings his bug-finding expertise to security oversight. Shelly serves as our FedRAMP Coordinator and helps keep everything organized.

content.title: Regular Reviews and Updates
content.content: The policy is reviewed and updated at least every three years, with Pete conducting annual reviews. Supporting procedures are updated at least yearly or when major changes occur (new tools, security incidents, etc.). All updates are disseminated to the team via email or brief all-hands meetings.

content.title: Why This Matters
content.content: Having a solid, updated policy shows management commitment and ensures accountability. It's our playbook for security training and demonstrates to auditors that we have our act together. Reading policy updates now prevents security problems later!

quiz.question: Who is the owner of ClearTriage's security training program?

modules.title: AT-2: Security & Privacy Literacy Training and Awareness
modules.description: Comprehensive security and privacy training covering ongoing awareness, insider threat recognition, and year-round security practices
objectives: Complete required security and privacy literacy training
Recognize insider threat indicators and reporting procedures
Understand ongoing security awareness throughout the year
Learn about our security culture and incident response

content.title: Security & Privacy Literacy Training
content.content: This module covers our ongoing security and privacy training requirements. Every new team member completes this training during onboarding (within the first week), and all team members retake it annually. We also provide just-in-time training when changes or incidents occur.

content.title: Training Schedule and Requirements
content.content: New hire training happens Day 1 (or within first week) covering password rules, data handling, phishing awareness, and AWS/Google Drive security. Annual refresher training occurs every 12 months via group sessions. Additional training provided after significant changes, incidents, or near-misses.

content.title: Year-Round Security Awareness
content.content: Beyond formal training, we maintain ongoing awareness through: Email/Slack security tips, brief team meeting discussions, interactive exercises like phishing simulations, visible system prompts and reminders, and fostering a culture where security concerns are encouraged and welcomed.

content.title: Insider Threat Awareness
content.content: An insider threat occurs when someone with authorized access misuses it to harm the organization - either intentionally or accidentally. This includes current employees, contractors, or ex-employees with lingering access. Everyone serves as a sensor for potential insider threats.

content.title: Insider Threat Indicators
content.content: Watch for: Unusual data downloading/accessing, bypassing security controls, unusual hours/access patterns, significant behavior changes or disgruntlement, internal social engineering attempts, and negligent security practices. Trust your instincts - if something seems off, speak up.

content.title: Reporting and Response
content.content: Report any insider threat concerns immediately to Pete Allen (pete@cleartriage.com) or Dave as backup. Don't wait or tell others first. Reports are handled confidentially, and false alarms are better than missed threats. Pete will investigate discreetly and take appropriate action, including account disabling if necessary.

content.title: Security Culture
content.content: We encourage a culture where security is part of everyday thinking. You won't get in trouble for raising security concerns - it's encouraged! Share news about vulnerabilities, ask about suspicious emails, and help each other stay secure. We prefer false alarms over missed real threats.

modules.title: AT-3: Role-Based Security Training
modules.description: Specialized security training tailored to specific job roles and responsibilities within ClearTriage
objectives: Understand role-specific security requirements and training
Learn specialized security practices for your job function
Identify when and how role-based training is delivered
Recognize the importance of training before privileged access

content.title: Role-Based Security Training
content.content: While everyone receives baseline security awareness training, we also provide specialized training based on your specific job duties. In our six-person team, you might wear multiple hats, so we group responsibilities to ensure everyone gets relevant training for their roles.

content.title: Technical/Developer Roles
content.content: Developers and DevOps engineers (Savvy, Braden) receive specialized training on: secure coding practices, code review with security mindset, secure AWS configuration, vulnerability management, and incident response. This includes avoiding common vulnerabilities like SQL injection and XSS, plus proper management of access keys and secrets. Training required before production access and annually thereafter.

content.title: Operational/Administrative Roles
content.content: Operations and administrative staff (like Shelly as FedRAMP Coordinator) receive training on: data handling procedures, privacy considerations, policy compliance, customer support security, recognizing social engineering attempts, and maintaining confidentiality. This includes secure use of Google Drive and verifying customer identity before sharing information.

content.title: Executive/Leadership Roles
content.content: Leadership (Pete as CTO, Dave as President) receives training on: understanding compliance requirements (FedRAMP, VA requirements), risk management, driving security culture, staying current with FedRAMP updates, and responding to security audits. Leaders must champion security by example and strategic understanding.

content.title: Sales & Clinical Roles
content.content: Krista (Director of Sales and Clinical Education) receives specialized training on: handling customer communications securely, discussing security features without revealing sensitive details, and leveraging her nursing background's confidentiality and verification experience for our VA customer base.

content.title: Multiple Roles and Cross-Training
content.content: Team members filling multiple roles receive all relevant training modules. We integrate content rather than duplicate time. For example, a developer doing customer support gets both technical and operational training. This provides a well-rounded security perspective across job functions.

content.title: Timing and Tracking
content.content: Role-based training is completed before privileged access is granted and annually thereafter. We maintain a simple matrix tracking who needs what training. Content is reviewed and updated at least annually, incorporating new features, procedure changes, and lessons learned from incidents.
